block-definition.comment: This block allows you to set the pen's color, transparency (on a scale from 0=opaque to 100=invisible), or size (in pixels). The color can be set in many ways, including RGB values, HSV values, HSL values, fair HSV or HSL (based on a modified spectrum that gives each spectral color equal space and promotes brown to a color), color number, crayon, or X11/W3C color name. See Appendix A in the Snap! Reference Manual for details.

input.options: color color number crayon fair hue ~1 size transparency X11/W3C name ~2 (3D color spaces)={ fair HSL={ fair hue fair saturation (HSL) fair lightness fair HSL vector } fair HSV={ fair hue fair saturation (HSV) fair value (brightness) fair HSV vector } HSL={ hue saturation (HSL) lightness HSL vector } HSV={ hue saturation (HSV) value (brightness) HSV vector } RGB (0-255)={ red green blue RGB(A) vector RGB(A) hex } }

scripts.comment: Note to myself: When the user sets a fair dimension, say fair HSL, variable HSL contains the corresponding "unfair" values, and "raw HSL" contains the numbers the user actually gave. It has to be this way because in the case of HSV, there is no "HSV" variable; rather, we use the pen's actual remembered-by-Javascript color's HSV coordinates. So our HSL variable has to be analogous to that. In both cases "raw" means the numbers the user gave us.

custom-block.s: set pen color to h: %n s: %n v: %n

block-definition.translations: pt:lana o erro _

custom-block.s: set pen color to r: %n g: %n b: %n

de:wirf _ ca:llana _ es:lanzar _ fr:lance _ pt:lana _
de:ignoriere _ ca:ignora _ es:ignorar _ fr:ignore _ pt:ignora _

block-definition.comment: Sets the pen color to one of 100 preselected colors, like a box of 100 crayons. The colors have names that are meant to be evocative. They are organized in families, more or less corresponding to spectral (rainbow) colors; the input slot has a two-level menu in which you can hover over a family name to see the colors of that family, each including a crayon number and an RGB value. See Appendix A of the Snap! Reference Manual for more details.

input.options: grays={ 0 black #000000=0 1 gray7 #121212=1 2 gray14 #242424=2 3 gray21 #363636=3 4 gray28 #484848=4 5 gray36 #5c5c5c=5 6 gray43 #6d6d6d=6 7 gray50 #7f7f7f=7 8 gray57 #919191=8 9 gray64 #a3a3a3=9 10 gray71 #b5b5b5=10 11 gray78 #c8c8c8=11 12 gray85 #dadada=12 13 gray92 #ececec=13 14 white #ffffff=14 } pinks={ 15 deep pink #ff1493=15 16 hot pink #ff69b4=16 17 bright pink #ff007f=17 18 raspberry #e30b5d=18 19 amaranth #e52b50=19 } reds={ 20 red #ff0000=20 21 burgundy #900020=21 22 cherry #990000=22 23 dark candy apple red #a40000=23 24 sanguine #c00000=24 25 maroon #800000=25 26 crimson #c90016=26 27 Lists #d94d11=27 28 candy apple red #ff0800=28 29 coquelicot #ff3800=29 } browns={ 30 saddle brown #8b4513=30 31 chocolate #7b3f00=31 32 kobicha #6b4423=32 33 sepia #704214=33 34 chestnut #954535=34 35 dark brown #654321=35 36 brown #964b00=36 37 golden brown #996515=37 38 cinnamon #b87333=38 39 copper #d2691e=39 } oranges={ 40 orange #ff7f00=40 41 Pantone orange #ff5800=41 42 pumpkin #ff7518=42 43 Variables #f3761d=43 44 Spanish orange #e86100=44 45 burnt orange #cc5500=45 46 sinopia #cb410b=46 47 ochre #cc7722=47 48 carrot #ed9121=48 49 tangerine #f28500=49 } yellows={ 50 yellow #ffff00=50 51 Control #e6a822=51 52 dark goldenrod #b8860b=52 53 goldenrod #daa520=53 54 saffron #f4c430=54 55 sandstorm #ecd540=55 56 mustard #ffdb58=56 57 gold #ffd700=57 58 egg yolk #fee33e=58 59 rubber duck #fbe108=59 } greens={ 60 lime #00ff00=60 61 apple green #8db600=61 62 Operators #62c213=62 63 forest green #228b22=63 64 green #008000=64 65 dark green #006400=65 66 dark pastel green #03c03c=66 67 emerald #50c878=67 68 mint #3eb489=68 69 Pen #00a178=69 } cyans={ 70 aqua (cyan) #00ffff=70 71 dark cyan #008b8b=71 72 cerulean #007ba7=72 73 iceberg #71a6d2=73 74 Sensing #0494dc=74 75 teal #008080=75 76 light sky blue #87cefa=76 77 deep sky blue #00bfff=77 78 dodger blue #1e90ff=78 79 azure #007fff=79 } blues={ 80 blue #0000ff=80 81 midnight blue #191970=81 82 dark powder blue #003399=82 83 cobalt #0047ab=83 84 denim #1560bd=84 85 navy blue #000080=85 86 steel blue #4682b4=86 87 Motion #4a6cd4=87 88 cornflower #6495ed=88 89 slate blue #6a5acd=89 } purples={ 90 violet #8000ff=90 91 Looks #8f56e3=91 92 grape #6f2da8=92 93 indigo #4b0082=93 94 x11 purple #a020f0=94 95 magenta (fuchia) #ff00ff=95 96 dark orchid #9932cc=96 97 Sound #cf4ad9=97 98 purple #7f007f=98 99 dark magenta #8b008b=99 }

custom-block.s: set pen color to r: %n g: %n b: %n

block-definition.s: set pen color to r: %'r' g: %'g' b: %'b'
block-definition.comment: Takes three inputs for red, green, and blue values, each between 0 and 255. 0,0,0 is black; 255,255,255 is white. 255,255,0 is yellow, and so on. The SET PEN block in this library lets you set individual red, green, or blue without changing the others, lets you provide a list of three RGB color components, and lets you provide a six-digit hexadecimal number, the form in which RGB color values are usually found online. See Appendix A of the Snap! Reference Manual for details.
block-definition.translations: pt:altera a cor da tua caneta para vermelho _ , verde _ e azul _ (0 a 255)

block-definition.s: set pen color to h: %'h' s: %'s' v: %'v'
block-definition.comment: Takes three inputs for hue, saturation, and value ("brightness") values, each between 0 and 1. 0,0,0 is black; 0,0,1 is white. 0.15,1,1 is yellow, and so on. The SET PEN block in this library lets you set individual hue, saturation, or value without changing the others, lets you provide a list of three HSV color components, and lets you use the very much superior HSL (hue, saturation, lightness) color space. See Appendix A of the Snap! Reference Manual for details.
block-definition.translations: pt:altera a cor da caneta para matiz _ , saturao _ e brilho _ (0 a 1)

block-definition.comment: Reports the current pen color as a list of three RGB values in the range 0-255. The PEN block in this library provides a large set of ways to examine the color. See Appendix A in the Snap! Reference Manual for details.
block-definition.translations: pt:a cor da caneta em RGB (vermelho, verde e azul; 0 a 255)

block-definition.comment: Reports the current pen color as a list of three HSV values in the range 0-1. See Appendix A in the Snap! Reference Manual for details.
block-definition.translations: pt:a cor da caneta em HSV (matiz, saturao e brilho, 0 a 1)

block-definition.comment: Reports the part of the first string up to the first instance of the second string inside it. If the second string isn't found, reports the entire first string.
block-definition.translations: pt:o texto de _ antes de _

custom-block.s: substring of %txt from position %n to position %n inclusive

block-definition.comment: If input is TRUE, comparisons made by functions in the string library will be case-independent (so "FOO" = "foo"). This is the default. If input is FALSE, comparisons will be exact.
block-definition.translations: pt:altera comparaes ignorando distino minsculas/maisculas para _

block-definition.comment: This block creates new variables on the selected scope: global (for all sprites), sprite (for this sprite only) or script (only for that blocks stack) with the names given (in 'names' list). If there is already a variable with that name in that scope, it does nothing: no errors and no overwrites.
block-definition.translations: pt:cria as variveis _ _ ca:crea les _ variables _ es:crear las _ variables _ de:erstellen _ var _

block-definition.comment: This block reports "true" if there is a variable with this given name (input slot) in that context. It can be a global, sprite or script variable. Otherwise it reports "false".
block-definition.translations: pt:a varivel _ existe ca:existeix la variable _ ? es:existe la variable _ ? de:existiert var _ ?

block-definition.comment: The maximum number of tokens to generate in the completion. The token count of your prompt plus max_tokens cannot exceed the model's context length. Most models have a context length of 2048 tokens.

Number between -2.0 and 2.0. Positive values penalize new tokens based on whether they appear in the text so far, increasing the model's likelihood to talk about new topics. More info at https://beta.openai.com/docs/api-reference/parameter-details

Number between -2.0 and 2.0. Positive values penalize new tokens based on their existing frequency in the text so far, decreasing the model's likelihood to repeat the same line verbatim. More info at https://beta.openai.com/docs/api-reference/parameter-details

block-definition.s: stop completing before generating any of %'stop'
Hugging face model %'model name' with key %'api key' $nl with input %'data'
block-definition.comment: Can communicate with over 15,000 models. The API key can be obtained from huggingface.co More information at https://ecraft2learn.github.io/ai/AI-Teacher-Guide/chapter-5.html#hugging-face

custom-block.comment: Send the request to Hugging Face.
Turn the response from JSON to Snap! lists.

block.comment: Check if there is an error

custom-block.comment: If the error is that the model isn't ready then wait.

block.comment: Estimates seem too large so try 1/2

custom-block.s: Hugging face model %txt with key %txt %br with input %mult%s

block-definition.comment: Reports the character position (starting from 1) of the beginning of the first input string inside the second input string. If it's not found, reports 0.
block-definition.translations: pt:a posio de _ em _ ca:posici de _ en _

block-definition.comment: Reports True if the first input string contains the second input string, otherwise false. Comparison is case-independent by default; use USE CASE-INDEPENDENT COMPARISONS to change that.
block-definition.translations: pt:o texto de _ antes de _ ca:text _ cont _ ?

block-definition.comment: Reports the input text with lower case letters instead of capital letters in the input. Uses the user's locale's rules for case conversion.
block-definition.translations: pt:em minsculas _ ca:_ a minscules
ca:comparacions ignorant majscules?

block-definition.s: text or texts input %'text or texts'
block-definition.comment: Input can either be text or a list of texts.

What sampling temperature to use. Higher values means the model will take more risks. Try 0.9 for more creative applications, and 0 (argmax sampling) for ones with a well-defined answer. We generally recommend altering this or top_p but not both.
Reports the first voice number that matches all the arguments. If nothing matches tries to find a voice that matches the first argument.

custom-block.s: check for voices %cmdRing if no voices otherwise do %cmdRing

block-definition.s: check for voices %'do if no voices' if no voices otherwise do %'do if voices'
Speak %'message' $nl with pitch %'pitch' $nl with rate %'rate' $nl with voice %'voice' $nl with volume %'volume' $nl in language %'language' $nl wait %'wait' before doing the next command
block-definition.comment: Speaks 'message'. Optionally you can provide the pitch (a positive number), rate (a number between .1 and 2), voice name or number (depends upon what voices are accessible from the browser - see 'get voice names'), volume (a positive number), and language code or name. This command will wait until it is finished if wait is true.

block-definition.s: edit %'input' using GPT-3 with instructions %'instruction' with key %'api key' $nl with options %'options'
block-definition.comment: Ask the specified GPT-3 engine to edit the input. Input 3 must be your OpenAI API key which you can obtain from https://openai.com For documentation on the options see https://beta.openai.com/docs/api-reference/edits/

inputs.input: What dey of the wek is it?

block.comment: Ignore empty options.
Extracts the completion text from the response.
Extracts the error message from the response.

inputs.input: adaada babbage curie davinci j1-jumbo j1-large small medium large xlarge

list.l: Edit the story that Kenny could find out more about his mysterious bullet from the internet, or by talking to a gun expert.

custom-block.l: Kenny was out exploring the Indiana Dunes when he found something shiny in the sand. It was a 50-caliber bullet! Kenny was excited to show his friends his new prize. He had no idea where it came from, but he knew it was something special. As Kenny walked home, he wondered what could have fired such a big bullet. He had never seen anything like it before. He was sure it must have come from a very powerful gun. Maybe even a military-grade weapon! Kenny couldnt wait to find out more about his mysterious bullet.

Kenny was out exploring the Indiana Dunes when he found something shiny in the sand. It was a 50-caliber bullet! Kenny was excited to show his friends his new prize. He had no idea where it came from, but he knew it was something special. As Kenny walked home, he wondered what could have fired such a big bullet. He had never seen anything like it before. He was sure it must have come from a very powerful gun. Maybe even a military-grade weapon! Kenny couldnt wait to find out more about his mysterious bullet. He could find out more about it from the internet, or by talking to a gun expert.

Kenny was out exploring the Indiana Dunes when he found something shiny in the sand. It was a 50-caliber bullet! Kenny was excited to show his friends his new prize. He had no idea where it came from, but he knew it was something special. As Kenny walked home, he wondered what could have fired such a big bullet. He had never seen anything like it before. He was sure it must have come from a very powerful gun. Maybe even a military-grade weapon! Kenny couldnt wait to find out more about his mysterious bullet. He could find out more about it from the internet, or by talking to a gun expert. He could also ask a police officer to help him identify the bullet.

He had no idea where it came from, but he knew it was something special. As Kenny walked home, he wondered what could have fired such a big bullet. He had never seen anything like it before. Kenny was out exploring the Indiana Dunes when he found something shiny in the sand. It was a 50-caliber bullet! Kenny was excited to show his friends his new prize. He had no idea where it came from, but he knew it was something special. He thought about it for a moment and realized that the bullet must have come from a powerful gun. Maybe even a military-grade weapon! Kenny couldnt wait to find out more about his mysterious bullet. He could find out more about it from the internet, or by talking to a gun expert. He could also ask a police officer to help him identify the bullet. As Kenny walked home, he wondered what could have fired such a big bullet. He had never seen anything like it before.

He had no idea where it came from, but he knew it was something special. He thought about it for a moment and realized that the bullet must have come from a powerful gun. Kenny was out exploring the Indiana Dunes when he found something shiny in the sand. It was a 50-caliber bullet! Kenny was excited to show his friends his new prize. He had no idea where it came from, but he knew it was something special. He thought about it for a moment and realized that the bullet must have come from a powerful gun. Maybe even a military-grade weapon! Kenny couldnt wait to find out more about his mysterious bullet. He could find out more about it from the internet, or by talking to a gun expert. He could also ask a police officer to help him identify the bullet. As Kenny walked home, he wondered what could have fired such a big bullet. He had never seen anything like it before. He was curious about where the bullet came from and why it was in the sand.

list.l: No provider known for language model:

block-definition.s: get API key of %'service provider' and explain %'explain flag' and ask %'ask flag'

list.l: You need to have an API key from
Your key should be kept secret and not shared.
We recommend you read the scripts of this project to be sure your keys will be safe.
You can get a key from

custom-block.l: We can store your key in the browser's local storage. We recommend this only if you are the only user of this computer.

block.l: Enter your key or just press enter if this is a shared computer
OK.Now it is safe to enter your key. It will not be stored.

block-definition.comment: The second input is an "association list," a list of two-item lists. Each of those smaller lists has a "key" as its first item and a "value" as its second. ASSOC reports the first key-value pair in the association list whose key matches the first input.
block-definition.translations: ca:associaci _ _

block-definition.comment: What sampling temperature to use. Higher values means the model will take more risks. A temperature of zero will always take the most like next token (word) which is good when expecting a well-defined answer. 'temperature' should normally be between 0 and 1. But OpenAI accepts values up to 2 and others up to 5. We generally recommend altering this or top_p but not both. More info at https://beta.openai.com/docs/api-reference/parameter-details https://studio.ai21.com/docs/api/#request https://docs.cohere.ai/generate-reference#request

input.options: ada babbage curie davinci j1-jumbo j1-large small medium large xlarge

block-definition.s: maximum number of tokens %'max' for model named %'model'
block-definition.comment: The maximum number of tokens to generate in the completion. The token count of your prompt plus max tokens cannot exceed the model's context length. Most models have a context length of 2048 tokens. More tokens takes more time and costs more. More info at https://beta.openai.com/docs/api-reference/parameter-details https://studio.ai21.com/docs/api/#request https://docs.cohere.ai/generate-reference#request

inputs.input: GPT-3ada babbage curie davinci j1-jumbo j1-large small medium large xlarge

block-definition.comment: High values penalize new tokens based on whether they appear in the text so far, increasing the model's likelihood to talk about new topics. 'penality' should range from 0 to 1. More info at https://beta.openai.com/docs/api-reference/parameter-details https://studio.ai21.com/docs/api/#repetition-penalties https://docs.cohere.ai/generate-reference#request

input.options: ada babbage curie davinci j1-jumbo j1-large small medium large xlarge

block-definition.comment: High values penalize new tokens based on their existing frequency in the text so far, decreasing the model's likelihood to repeat the same line verbatim. 'penality' should range from 0 to 1. More info at https://beta.openai.com/docs/api-reference/parameter-details https://studio.ai21.com/docs/api/#repetition-penalties https://docs.cohere.ai/generate-reference#request

input.options: ada babbage curie davinci j1-jumbo j1-large small medium large xlarge

custom-block.s: substring of %txt from position %n to position %n inclusive
substring of %txt from position %n to position %n inclusive

block-definition.s: substring of %'str' from position %'start' to position %'end' inclusive
block-definition.comment: Reports the portion of the first input (string) starting at the position given by the second input (counting from 1, like LETTER n OF) and ending at the position given by the third input (also counting from 1). If the third input is empty, reports the portion from the first position to the end of the string. If a position number is negative, counts from the end backward, so -1 is the last character, -2 is the next to last, etc.
block-definition.translations: pt:o texto de _ entre as posies _ e _ , inclusive

scripts.comment: This area is used for doing experiments. Note that the 'Clipboard write" command is a shortcut for saving results to documents and relies upon JavaScript extension. Instead one can use the Snap! export facility instead.

block.l: Abundance of Ideas by Neil Gaiman

list.l: A train full of silent women plunging forever through the twilight
A man who inherits a library card to the library of Alexandria
A rosebush, a nightingale, and a black rubber dog collar
A city in which the streets are paved with time
A small piece of blue cardboard
A plum, sweet and tart and cold
A were-goldfish who transforms into a wolf at full moon
Two old women taking a weasel on a holiday
A man who falls in love with a paper doll
The sun setting over the Parthenon
An old man in Sunderland who owned the universe, and who kept it in a jam jar in the dusty cupboard under the stairs

custom-block.s: complete %txt using GPT-3 engine named %txt with key %txt %br with options %mult%txt

list.l: Here are descriptions of illustrations for the text on pages from an illustrated book.

custom-block.s: get API key of %txt and explain %b and ask %b

custom-block.l: A girl named Sigrid who is called CC. She is almost 2 years old and lives with her brother Ellis. She likes kicking balls.
A boy named Ellis. He is almost 4 years old and lives with his little sister Sigrid. He likes playing with robots.

Karen was looking for her favorite sweater in her closet when the door suddenly closed, trapping her thumb in the process. Karen let out a cry of pain as she tried to free her thumb, but it was no use. She tried everything she could think of, but the door wouldn't budge. Finally, she resigned herself to the fact that she was going to have to wait for someone to come home and help her. She sat down on the floor and tried to make herself as comfortable as possible, but it was hard with the pain in her thumb. She must have dozed off, because the next thing she knew, she heard the front door open and close. She called out for help, and her mom came rushing into the closet. She was able to get the door open and free Karen's thumb. Karen was so relieved that she burst into tears. Her mom hugged her and promised that she would never let anything like that happen to her again.

Edit the story to add more detail to make the story more interesting. For example, you could describe the pain Karen feels in her thumb, or the various thoughts that go through her mind as she sits in the closet waiting for help.let
Here is the new version of the story:

custom-block.s: complete %txt using model named %txt with key %txt %br with options %mult%txt
get API key of %txt and explain %b and ask %b
maximum number of tokens %n for model named %txt

custom-block.l: You will be asked to follow editing instructions to create a new version of a passage of text. Text:

Text: A girl eats the little bear's porridge, breaks his little chair, and falls asleep in his little bed. Illustration: A girl sleeping in a small bed next to a broken chair and an empty bowl. Text: Her fairy godmother appears and transforms a pumpkin into a golden coach to take Cinderella to the ball. Illustration: A girl is riding in a pumpkin-shaped carriage. Text: A hungry grasshopper begs for food from an ant when winter comes and is refused. Illustration: A hungry grasshopper is begging an ant. Text: Now when the men observed the earth through the lower window, it looked like nothing more than a dark spot, drowned in the solar rays. Illustration: Men looking out of a window at the Earth from far away.

custom-block.comment: A nice way of seeing any particular version

block.comment: If you want illustration prompts for a different version of the story choose the version and run this.

The closer this value is to 1 the more creative it is but maybe less sensible.

watcher.var: Abundance of Ideas by Neil Gaiman

variable.name: story description
variable.l: A girl named Karen hurt her thumb when a closet door closed.

variable.name: story
variable.l: Karen is a little girl who loves to play dress up. She has a closet full of pretty clothes, and she loves to try them all on. One day, she decides to try on her favorite dress. She puts it on and goes to look in the mirror. She loves how it looks on her and decides to leave it on for the rest of the day. Karen is a little girl who is looking for her favorite sweater in her closet. Karen was looking for her favorite sweater in her closet when the door suddenly closed, trapping her thumb in the process. Karen let out a cry of pain as she tried to free her thumb, but it was no use. She tried everything she could think of, but the door wouldnt budge. She was stuck. Finally, she resigned herself to the fact that she was going to have to wait for someone to come home and help her. She sat down on the floor and tried to make herself as comfortable as possible, but it was hard with the pain in her thumb. She must have dozed off, because the next thing she knew, she heard the front door open and close. She called out for help, and her mom came rushing into the closet. Her mom was able to get the door open and free Karens thumb. Karen was so relieved that she burst into tears. Her mom hugged her and promised that she would never let anything like that happen to her again. She then took Karen back to the living room and they had some ice cream to celebrate Karens freedom.

variable.name: story evolution
variable.l: Description: A girl named Karen hurt her thumb when a closet door closed. Story: Karen was looking for her favorite sweater in her closet when the door suddenly closed, trapping her thumb in the process. Karen let out a cry of pain as she tried to free her thumb, but it was no use. She tried everything she could think of, but the door wouldn't budge. Finally, she resigned herself to the fact that she was going to have to wait for someone to come home and help her. She sat down on the floor and tried to make herself as comfortable as possible, but it was hard with the pain in her thumb. She must have dozed off, because the next thing she knew, she heard the front door open and close. She called out for help, and her mom came rushing into the closet. She was able to get the door open and free Karen's thumb. Karen was so relieved that she burst into tears. Her mom hugged her and promised that she would never let anything like that happen to her again. Summary: Karen gets her thumb trapped in the door of her closet and has to wait for her mom to come home and help her. She is relieved and promises her mom that she will never let anything like that happen to her again. Instruction: Edit the story to add more detail to make the story more interesting. For example, you could describe the pain Karen feels in her thumb, or the various thoughts that go through her mind as she sits in the closet waiting for help. Story: Karen was looking for her favorite sweater in her closet when the door suddenly closed, trapping her thumb in the process. Karen let out a cry of pain as she tried to free her thumb, but it was no use. She tried everything she could think of, but the door wouldnt budge. She was stuck. Finally, she resigned herself to the fact that she was going to have to wait for someone to come home and help her. She sat down on the floor and tried to make herself as comfortable as possible, but it was hard with the pain in her thumb. She must have dozed off, because the next thing she knew, she heard the front door open and close. She called out for help, and her mom came rushing into the closet. Her mom was able to get the door open and free Karens thumb. Karen was so relieved that she burst into tears. Her mom hugged her and promised that she would never let anything like that happen to her again. Instruction: Edit the story to add a sentence or two at the beginning of the story to establish the setting and why Karen is in the closet. Another suggestion is to add more detail to the description of Karen's experience, such as what she was thinking and feeling as she tried to free her thumb. Karen was looking for her favorite sweater in her closet when the door suddenly closed, trapping her thumb in the process. Finally, she resigned herself to the fact that she was going to have to wait for someone to come home and help her. She sat down on the floor and tried to make herself as comfortable as possible, but it was hard with the pain in her thumb. Instruction: Edit the story to add more detail to the story, such as what happened after Karen's mom freed her from the closet. Story: Karen is a little girl who loves to play dress up. She has a closet full of pretty clothes, and she loves to try them all on. One day, she decides to try on her favorite dress. She puts it on and goes to look in the mirror. She loves how it looks on her and decides to leave it on for the rest of the day. Karen is a little girl who is looking for her favorite sweater in her closet. Karen was looking for her favorite sweater in her closet when the door suddenly closed, trapping her thumb in the process. Karen let out a cry of pain as she tried to free her thumb, but it was no use. She tried everything she could think of, but the door wouldnt budge. She was stuck. Finally, she resigned herself to the fact that she was going to have to wait for someone to come home and help her. She sat down on the floor and tried to make herself as comfortable as possible, but it was hard with the pain in her thumb. She must have dozed off, because the next thing she knew, she heard the front door open and close. She called out for help, and her mom came rushing into the closet. Her mom was able to get the door open and free Karens thumb. Karen was so relieved that she burst into tears. Her mom hugged her and promised that she would never let anything like that happen to her again. She then took Karen back to the living room and they had some ice cream to celebrate Karens freedom. Summary: Karen gets her thumb stuck in the door of her closet while looking for a favorite sweater and has to wait for her mom to come home and help her. They celebrate her freedom with some ice cream.

Karen is a little girl who is looking for her favorite sweater in her closet. Karen was looking for her favorite sweater in her closet when the door suddenly closed, trapping her thumb in the process. Karen let out a cry of pain as she tried to free her thumb, but it was no use. She tried everything she could think of, but the door wouldnt budge. She was stuck. Finally, she resigned herself to the fact that she was going to have to wait for someone to come home and help her. She sat down on the floor and tried to make herself as comfortable as possible, but it was hard with the pain in her thumb. She must have dozed off, because the next thing she knew, she heard the front door open and close. She called out for help, and her mom came rushing into the closet. Her mom was able to get the door open and free Karens thumb. Karen was so relieved that she burst into tears. Her mom hugged her and promised that she would never let anything like that happen to her again. ","Karen is a little girl who loves to play dress up. She has a closet full of pretty clothes, and she loves to try them all on. One day, she decides to try on her favorite dress. She puts it on and goes to look in the mirror. She loves how it looks on her and decides to leave it on for the rest of the day. Karen is a little girl who is looking for her favorite sweater in her closet. Karen was looking for her favorite sweater in her closet when the door suddenly closed, trapping her thumb in the process. Karen let out a cry of pain as she tried to free her thumb, but it was no use. She tried everything she could think of, but the door wouldnt budge. She was stuck. Finally, she resigned herself to the fact that she was going to have to wait for someone to come home and help her. She sat down on the floor and tried to make herself as comfortable as possible, but it was hard with the pain in her thumb. She must have dozed off, because the next thing she knew, she heard the front door open and close. She called out for help, and her mom came rushing into the closet. Her mom was able to get the door open and free Karens thumb. Karen was so relieved that she burst into tears. Her mom hugged her and promised that she would never let anything like that happen to her again. She then took Karen back to the living room and they had some ice cream to celebrate Karens freedom. "

variable.name: instruction
variable.l: Edit the story to add more detail to the story, such as what happened after Karen's mom freed her from the closet.
